First off, that has nothing to do with "ball of stats."

Second, I don't really feel like that would balance him.  In fact, it would make him, like Rek'Sai, an even more oppressive early game counter-jungler.  He is already an excellent early game duelist and ganker; giving him Rek'sai vision would be a huge buff to his ability to "see" past walls.  Since you also still get allied vision, his ganks would not suffer in any significant way; worse, he'd probably have an easier time telling if there is a counter-gank.

Rek'sai's sonar is NOT a disadvantage.  It is DIFFERENT than normal vision, but in the ways that it is less effective than normal vision, it makes up for it in being able to do more than normal vision.

Are you joking? Having instant aoe magic damage that deals **200 + 100% Bonus AD lategame and has the potential to slow all targets struck by 60% is amazing . . .**

So he can't build penetration for it? Your point? The fact is that mixed damage allows for some sort of defensive against someone who is counter building your ludicrously high base physical damages. 380 + 180% + 8% Of Target's Missing Health Maxed Q or 600 + 200% Bonus AD to initial and all further struck enemies R.
And looking at it now, a base 200 damage for cripple, 200 for shield, and 600 for a single target ult AREN'T that good of base damages! His q is potent, but thats about it for base damages.

Compared to other similar abilities Lee's E does fairly well in terms of damage. It does more damage than Cull the Meek, Ki-burst, Tantrum, Sinister Steel, Crescent Slash and Shadow Slash. It equals Rampage and only gets outdamaged by Empowerd Cull the Meek, and Decimate.

The base damage isn't bad compared to things like ki burst because ki burst also is an AoE stun. Tantrum can be used every 3 seconds or so, cull the meek can do significantly MORE base damage (and doesn't have a resource cost at all) and heals, and decimate does MORE base damage (210) while being capable of doing a max 315. From what you mentioned, most of those abilites are actually stronger and if they were to be switched on Lee's build for Cripple, it would be considered broken. 

Sona's shield only gives 155, but its an aura so it effects multiple allies AND has a heal to go along with it. On top of that, it scales with AP which means sona will actually be able to make use of it. Lee isn't building any AP so the devs KNOW that it has to have a decent base stat. The same can be said for moves like Panth's ult. 

And as for the single target thing: yes if it hits all 5 people it does a lot of damage. But thats how AoE works. Youre never going to hit all 5 people when playing against a good team. And if you do manage to do it, its not about you being good; its about them being bad. Amumu's ult has a base damage of 350 and is guaranteed to hit multiple opponents AND has a 2 second stun. Graves has a similar pattern to lee's ult kick, has a base damage of 440 to those behind him (even more to the first target), has a wider hit box (will hit more people) AND is easier to hit because of his range! On top of that it scales better! Its an ult man, I don't know what you want me to tell you. Its powerful. You also have to be right up next to the person to do it and its difficult to land multiple hits. If it weren't powerful it wouldn't be an ult, but its not anywhere near OP. Many other ults have similar damages.

yo uwant to know one more thing, its thoughts like yours that are why the right champions don't get nerfed, people who play an op champion will fight for them, because in their own minds they have come up with ways to deal with them, but the truth of the matter is that most of the ways that you think lee is not op, are only true if he only had some of the things listed. if lee had access to his crazy mobility w but not his stupid undodgeable cc ult, he would not be op. if he didnt have so much early dominance and late game safety, he would not be op. do you really want to know the reason why lee sin is op? its because he has good enough ad scaling to not really fall off too hard late game, and he has enough utility to where when he does get his crap kicked early, ha can still come back and be a nuisance late game.

Ok no, and no. "Crazy mobility"? He has 1 guaranteed dash and that's it. There's no way he can use Q as a gap closer and still get off a good ult in a TF. If your carry gets hit by Q that's on you and you alone. It's like calling AP Nid op because her spears do so much damage.

Lee falls off late game, that's an irrefutable fact. His only shot late game is kicking a carry into his team and even if he does this, it's still a 1 for 1 trade. What the heck is Lee gonna do otherwise? Shield with no AP scaling? 
Oh, and AD scaling means absolutely nothing when you're behind on EXP and items. Either way, full damage Lee gets blown up as soon as he flies in.

Q might as well be resourceless.  Lee Sin loses virtually nothing by trying and missing with it, while similar abilities on mana champs eventually run them dry.

The problem with his base damage and scaling is that it allows him to build tanky and continue to duel people even late, while being useful and survivable in teamfights.  He is an easy playmaker, which means if you don't have him or someone who is just as easy to make plays with, you are at a disadvantage.  His consistently high pick at the highest levels of play show FAR beyond a shadow of a doubt that his kit is overloaded and his minor weaknesses are not enough to make up for his early dominance.  If you can't even admit that much, then you have no place in a discussion on balance.

Let's see you try anyway:  Why does Lee Sin maintain such high relevance in the pro scene, moreso than almost any other champion, if he is, as you think, underwhelming?

Didn't say he was UP, I said he wasn't OP. He has high relevance in the pro scene because his early game is great and he can itemize for his team. 90% of pro junglers build sightstone anyway and Lee directly benefits from it. He's consistent, he'll always be able to provide a set amount of utility for his team.  
Carry junglers are more risky than Lee, even though they do outscale him.
Edit: Resourceless Q means nothing later on. When mages have mana regen it's pretty much resourceless too.

You haven't played a mage lately, have you?

Anyway, that is the point.  His early game is WAY TOO GOOD for his utter lack of late game weaknesses.  He has too much utility to fall off late, so his early game needs to be less oppressive.

Lee Sin is also simple to counterplay whereas Sona can bully very hard with undodgeable abilities. She's still very strong, just not god tier like before.

Edit: Okay, Christ. To counter Lee Sin you keep him from snowballing by predicting when he's gonna use his abilities and ward so you can get out before he even ganks. If he's in lane, stay behind minions. He falls off late game, whether you like it or not. 

As for Sona, watch a pro play her. They nerfed her because of how strong she was in a pro's hands, not the majority of the community.

>Lee Sin is also simple to counterplay 

Where? How do I counter his kit? If Lee misses a Q he can just chase me down with ward hops and his super high base MS. If I try to engage on him he can kick me away and ward hop away creating around 1.5K units worth of distance. He pays no meaningful resource for his Q so it just becomes a matter of 'if he misses he can wait 6 seconds and try again'. The second Lee lands a Q on a priority target he can follow up and Insec them and if they're an immobile champ that's just too bad, flash or die.

Compare that to Sona, every time she does anything she has to move close to an ally, she's super squishy and puts herself at a huge risk of just being hard engaged on. That's ample counterplay.

I don't know when the community decided that skillshots=conterplay but it's not correct. If you don't lose much for using that skillshot or risk anything with ranges then it doesn't create any counterplay. A targeted skill like Sona's Q can create counterplay by forcing her into risky situations.

>She's still very strong, just not god tier like before.

It doesn't matter how strong a champ is if another champion does everything they do better. Nami is literally Sona V2. She has a stronger heal, non-ult CC, a stronger MS boost, less risky poke, a better AA enhancer and an all-round better ult. So why would you play Sona over Nami?
